snippet: Experts who examined the aircraft part found last week have “very strong presumptions” that it came from a Malaysian Boeing 777 that vanished in 2014.
abstract: Malaysian officials assert plane piece found on Reunion Island, France, belongs to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in March, 2014; experts from Boeing and National Transportation Safety Board ask for more analysis since modifications to part found do not match airline's  maintenance records; debris lacks unique identification number, making positive identification difficult.

byline.original: By AURELIEN BREEDEN and NICOLA CLARK
byline.contributor: Aurelien Breeden reported from Paris, and Nicola Clark from Ustica, Italy. Reporting was contributed by Michelle Innis from Sydney, Australia; Marc Santora from St.-Denis, Réunion Island; Michael Forsythe and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong; and Christopher Drew from New York. Adam Wu and Kiki Zhao contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Experts who examined the aircraft part found last week have “very strong presumptions” that it came from a Malaysian Boeing 777 that vanished in 2014.

headline.main: Réunion Debris Is Almost Surely From Flight 370, Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Debris Almost Surely Came From Lost Jet
